docs.title: PuzzleKit 🧰
docs.text: This is the documentation for PuzzleKit. Currently, 90 + solvers for logic puzzles are provided, which have been tested on 30k + instances. The dataset can be found in github repo puzzlekit-dataset.

docs.title: abc_end_view
docs.text:
Aliases: easy as abc

📖 Rule Reference: Read full rules on external site

🎮 Play Online: Play at puzz.link • janko

docs.title: Input Format
docs.text:
The input grid follows structure:

1. Header Line [ROWS] [COLS] [MAX_CHAR] * MAX_CHAR: The limit char (e.g., 'd' means filling with a, b, c, d).

2. Clue Lines (Next 4 lines) Space-separated characters representing hints from different view angles: * Line 2: Top views * Line 3: Bottom views * Line 4: Left views * Line 5: Right views

3. Grid Lines (Remaining [ROW] lines) The initial state of the grid rows.

Legend: * -: No clue / Empty cell; * a-z: Character hints.

docs.title: Output Format
docs.text:
Returns the solved grid as a matrix of characters.

  • Dimensions: [ROWS] lines x [COLS] characters.
  • Content: No external clues are included in the output.

Legend: * a-z: Filled characters * -: Empty cells (if the puzzle has blank spaces)

docs.title: Python Quick Start
docs.text:
Use the following code to solve this puzzle directly:

import puzzlekit

# Raw input data
problem_str = """
5 5 d
- - - - -
- - d b -
- - c b d
- c - a -
- - - - -
- - - - -
- - - - -
- - - - -
- - - - -
"""

# Solve
res = puzzlekit.solve(problem_str, puzzle_type="abc_end_view")

# Print solution grid
print(res.solution_data.get('solution_grid', []))

# Visualize (optional)
res.show()

docs.title: Solution Output
docs.text:
5 5 d
- b c a d
a d b c -
c - a d b
b c d - a
d a - b c

docs.title: balance_loop
docs.text:
Tags: loop

📖 Rule Reference: Read full rules on external site

🎮 Play Online: Play at puzz.link • janko

docs.title: Input Format
docs.text:
1. Header Line [ROWS] [COLS]

2. Grid Lines (Remaining [ROW] lines) The initial clues of the grid rows.

Legend: * -: Empty cell (no prefilled clue). * [color][number] (e.g., w4, b5): Circle with specified color and number. * [color] (e.g., w, b): Circle with specified color but no number.

Color Codes: * w: White circle * b: Black circle

docs.title: Output Format
docs.text:
Returns a grid with nswe format representing the path segments of the single continuous loop.

Cell Format:

Each non-empty cell contains a string of characters indicating the directions of the path passing through it.

  • n: North (Up)
  • s: South (Down)
  • w: West (Left)
  • e: East (Right)

Examples:

  • ns: A vertical line segment (North-South).
  • ne: A 90-degree turn connecting North and East.
  • -: Empty cell (not part of the loop).
  • x: Filled cell (not appear if no rule applies, e.g., masyu).

docs.title: Python Quick Start
docs.text:
Use the following code to solve this puzzle directly:

import puzzlekit

# Raw input data
problem_str = """
5 5
- - - - - 
- - - - - 
- - w4 - - 
- - - - - 
b5 - b - b3
"""

# Solve
res = puzzlekit.solve(problem_str, puzzle_type="balance_loop")

# Print solution grid
print(res.solution_data.get('solution_grid', []))

# Visualize (optional)
res.show()

docs.title: Solution Output
docs.text:

- se sw - -
se nw ns - -
ns - ne ew sw
ns - se sw ns
ne ew nw ne nw

docs.title: battleship
docs.text:
📖 Rule Reference: Read full rules on external site

🎮 Play Online: Play at puzz.link • janko

docs.title: Input Format
docs.text:
The battleship-style grid follows structure:

1. Header Line [ROWS] [COLS] [NUM OF SHIPS]

Note: [NUM OF SHIPS] is adaptively updated, you can specify the shape via sequance.

e.g., 5 4 0 2 1 means the number of ships with size 1,2,3,4,5 is 5,4,0,2,1 respectively. The largest ship is not limited, which means you can use: 5 8 8 9 0 0 3 0 5 6 2 sequcece to represent your fleet where the longest ship is 11.

2. Clue Lines (Next 4 lines)

Space-separated characters representing hints (cols and rows):

  • Line 2: Top column numbers.
  • Line 3: Left row numbers.

3. Clue Grid (Next [ROWS] lines)

Represents the numbers/clues given in the problem.

  • -: Empty cell (no number or ship).
  • x: forbidden water, no ships filled.
  • n: a ship pointing "North" (up).
  • s: a ship pointing "South" (Down).
  • w: a ship pointing "West" (Left).
  • e: a ship pointing "East" (Right).
  • o: a ship with length 1.
  • m: a middle segment of ship (with length > 1).

docs.title: Output Format
docs.text: Same format as input desc, only to omit the row/col hints.

import puzzlekit

# Raw input data

11 11 5 4 3 2 1
2 5 3 2 4 4 2 4 2 1 6
2 6 1 7 0 1 8 1 5 0 4
- - - - - - - x - - -
w - - x - - - - - - -
- - - - - - - - - - x
- - - - - x - x - - -
- - - - - - - - - - -
- - - - - - - - - - -
- - - - x - - - - - -
- - - - - - - - - - s
- - - - - - - - - - -
- - - - - - - - - - -
- - - - - - - - - - -
"""

# Solve
res = puzzlekit.solve(problem_str, puzzle_type="battleship")

# Print solution grid
print(res.solution_data.get('solution_grid', []))

# Visualize (optional)
res.show()

docs.title: country_road
docs.text:
Tags: loop

📖 Rule Reference: Read full rules on external site

🎮 Play Online: Play at puzz.link • Janko

docs.title: Input Format
docs.text:
The input matches the puzzle dimensions followed by two sequential grid layers: the clue grid and the region definition grid.

Structure:

1. Header Line [ROWS] [COLS]

2. Clue Grid (Next [ROWS] lines) Represents the numbers/clues given in the problem. - -: Empty cell (no number or signal). - [Integer]: The number clue associated with the region containing this cell. - w or b: white (w) circle or black (b) circle (if any, e.g., dotchi loop).

3. Region Grid (The following [ROWS] lines) Represents the boundary definitions of the puzzle. - Each cell contains a Region ID (character or integer). - Cells with the same ID belong to the same region (room/area).

docs.title: Output Format
docs.text:
Returns a grid with nswe format representing the path segments of the single continuous loop.

Cell Format:

Each non-empty cell contains a string of characters indicating the directions of the path passing through it.

  • n: North (Up)
  • s: South (Down)
  • w: West (Left)
  • e: East (Right)

Examples:

  • ns: A vertical line segment (North-South).
  • ne: A 90-degree turn connecting North and East.
  • -: Empty cell (not part of the loop).
  • x: Filled cell (not appear if no rule applies, e.g., masyu).

- - - - - - - - 3 -

- - - 3 - - 6 - - -
2 - - - - - - - 4 -
- - - - - - - - - -
1 1 6 6 11 13 13 13 18 18
1 1 6 6 11 13 13 13 18 18
2 2 6 6 12 12 12 16 16 16
2 2 7 9 9 9 9 16 16 16
2 2 7 9 9 9 9 17 19 19
3 3 7 9 9 9 9 17 20 20
4 4 4 9 9 9 9 17 20 20
4 4 4 10 10 10 15 15 20 20
5 5 8 8 8 14 15 15 21 21
5 5 8 8 8 14 15 15 21 21
"""

# Solve
res = puzzlekit.solve(problem_str, puzzle_type="country_road")

# Print solution grid
print(res.solution_data.get('solution_grid', []))

# Visualize (optional)
res.show()

docs.text:
Tags: shade

📖 Rule Reference: Read full rules on external site

🎮 Play Online: Play at puzz.link • Janko

docs.title: Input Format
docs.text:
1. Header Line

[ROWS] [COLS]

Note: [ROWS] [COLS] indicate the size of grid, since clues of creek appear in the corners of cells, the following grid is [ROWS + 1] by [COLS + 1], yet, the output grid size is [ROWS] [COLS].

2. Clue Grid (Next [ROWS + 1] lines, each line with [COLS + 1] clues)

Represents the numbers/clues given in the problem. * -: Empty corner clues (no number). * [Integer]: The number clue in this corner, each correspoding to the corner of row.

docs.title: Output Format
docs.text:
Returns the shade-variant grid as a matrix of cells, [ROWS] by [COLS].

Legend:

  • x: shaded cells;
  • -: blank cells;
  • other chars remain the same as input description legend.

docs.title: Python Quick Start
docs.text:
Use the following code to solve this puzzle directly:

import puzzlekit

# Raw input data
problem_str = """
10 10
- - - - - - - - - - -
- 2 2 - - 3 2 - - 1 -
- - - - 3 - - - 3 1 -
- - 2 - - 2 - - - 3 -
- - - 3 - 3 2 2 3 - -
- - - - - - - - - 2 -
- 2 3 - 2 2 - - - 3 -
- - - 2 - - - 2 - 3 -
- - 3 - - 3 - - 1 - -
- 3 - 3 - - - 2 - 2 -
- - - - - - - - - - -
"""

# Solve

docs.title: detour
docs.text:
Tags: loop

📖 Rule Reference: Read full rules on external site

🎮 Play Online: Play at puzz.link • Janko

docs.title: Input Format
docs.text:
The input matches the puzzle dimensions followed by two sequential grid layers: the clue grid and the region definition grid.

Structure:

1. Header Line [ROWS] [COLS]

2. Clue Grid (Next [ROWS] lines) Represents the numbers/clues given in the problem. - -: Empty cell (no number or signal). - [Integer]: The number clue associated with the region containing this cell. - w or b: white (w) circle or black (b) circle (if any, e.g., dotchi loop).

3. Region Grid (The following [ROWS] lines) Represents the boundary definitions of the puzzle. - Each cell contains a Region ID (character or integer). - Cells with the same ID belong to the same region (room/area).

docs.title: Output Format
docs.text:
Returns a grid with nswe format representing the path segments of the single continuous loop.

Cell Format:

Each non-empty cell contains a string of characters indicating the directions of the path passing through it.

  • n: North (Up)
  • s: South (Down)
  • w: West (Left)
  • e: East (Right)

Examples:

  • ns: A vertical line segment (North-South).
  • ne: A 90-degree turn connecting North and East.
  • -: Empty cell (not part of the loop).
  • x: Filled cell (not appear if no rule applies, e.g., masyu).

# Print solution grid
print(res.solution_data.get('solution_grid', []))

# Visualize (optional)
res.show()

docs.title: Input Format
docs.text:
The grid follows Structure:

Legend: - -: forbidden cells (no number); - 1-9: filled number.

docs.title: killer_sudoku
docs.text:
Tags: sudoku

📖 Rule Reference: Read full rules on external site

🎮 Play Online: Janko

docs.title: Input Format
docs.text:
The input matches the puzzle dimensions followed by two sequential grid layers: the clue grid and the region definition grid.

Structure:

1. Header Line [ROWS] [COLS]

2. Clue Grid (Next [ROWS] lines) Represents the numbers/clues given in the problem. - -: Empty cell (no number or signal). - [Integer]: The number clue associated with the region containing this cell. - w or b: white (w) circle or black (b) circle (if any, e.g., dotchi loop).

3. Region Grid (The following [ROWS] lines) Represents the boundary definitions of the puzzle. - Each cell contains a Region ID (character or integer). - Cells with the same ID belong to the same region (room/area).

docs.title: Output Format
docs.text:
Returns the sudoku-variant grid as a matrix of numbers, [ROWS] by [COLS].

Legend: - -: forbidden cells (no number); - 1-9: filled number.

🎮 Play Online: Play at puzz.link • janko

docs.title: Input Format
docs.text: TBD

docs.title: Output Format
docs.text:
Returns a grid with LITS format representing the path segments of the single continuous loop.

Cell Format:

Each non-empty cell contains a string of characters indicating the directions of the path passing through it.

  • L: Shape "L"
  • I: Shape "I"
  • T: Shape "T"
  • S: Shape "S"
  • -: Empty cell.

Tags: loop

📖 Rule Reference: Read full rules on external site

🎮 Play Online: Play at puzz.link • janko

docs.title: Input Format
docs.text: TBD

docs.title: Output Format
docs.text:
Returns a grid with nswe format representing the path segments of the single continuous loop.

Cell Format:

Each non-empty cell contains a string of characters indicating the directions of the path passing through it.

  • n: North (Up)
  • s: South (Down)
  • w: West (Left)
  • e: East (Right)

Examples:

  • ns: A vertical line segment (North-South).
  • ne: A 90-degree turn connecting North and East.
  • -: Empty cell (not part of the loop).
  • x: Filled cell (not appear if no rule applies, e.g., masyu).

docs.title: slitherlink
docs.text:
Tags: loop | Aliases: slither

📖 Rule Reference: Read full rules on external site

🎮 Play Online: Play at puzz.link • Janko

docs.title: Input Format
docs.text:
The grid follows:

Structure:

1. Header Line [ROWS] [COLS]

2. Clue Grid (Next [ROWS] lines)

Legend: - -: empty cells (no number); - [INTEGER]: filled number.

docs.title: Output Format
docs.text:
Returns the grid with "binary wall" format representing the path segments of the continuous "wall" loop.

Cell Format:

If all 4 walls are NOT connected, "-" and "0" are both acceptable.

Else, for each cell, a four-bit number "abcd" in decimal system is used to indicate the status of walls surrounding it.

  • a = 1 If the TOP wall is connected else 0,
  • b = 1 If the LEFT wall is connected else 0,
  • c = 1 If the BOTTOM wall is connected else 0,
  • d = 1 If the RIGHT wall is connected else 0,

Examples:

  • "12": if a cell has top, left walls connected, then the number (in binary system) is 1100, which equals "12" in decimal system, therefore, "12" is the value.
  • "7": if a cell has left, right and bottom walls connected, then the number (in binary system) is 0111, which equals "7" in decimal system, therefore, "7" is the value.
  • "-": if a cell has no connected walls, "-" is given.
  • x: filled cell (if any).

docs.title: Input Format
docs.text:
The yajilin-style grid follows structure:

1. Header Line [ROWS] [COLS]

2. Clue Grid (Next [ROWS] lines) Represents the numbers/clues given in the problem. - -: Empty cell (no number or signal). - [NUM][DIRECT]: e.g., 1w, 2s. The [NUM] is integer; the [DIRECT] is in 'nswe', means an arrow pointing n: North (Up), s: South (Down), w: West (Left), e: East (Right). - x: blacked cells (if any).

docs.title: Output Format
docs.text:
Returns the shade-variant grid as a matrix of cells, [ROWS] by [COLS].

Legend:

  • x: shaded cells;
  • -: blank cells;
  • other chars remain the same as input description legend.

docs.title: yajilin
docs.text:
Tags: loop

📖 Rule Reference: Read full rules on external site

🎮 Play Online: Play at puzzlink • Janko

docs.title: Input Format
docs.text:
The yajilin-style grid follows structure:

1. Header Line [ROWS] [COLS]

2. Clue Grid (Next [ROWS] lines) Represents the numbers/clues given in the problem. - -: Empty cell (no number or signal). - [NUM][DIRECT]: e.g., 1w, 2s. The [NUM] is integer; the [DIRECT] is in 'nswe', means an arrow pointing n: North (Up), s: South (Down), w: West (Left), e: East (Right). - x: blacked cells (if any).

docs.title: Output Format
docs.text:
Returns a grid with nswe format representing the path segments of the single continuous loop.

Cell Format:

Each non-empty cell contains a string of characters indicating the directions of the path passing through it.

  • n: North (Up)
  • s: South (Down)
  • w: West (Left)
  • e: East (Right)

Examples:

  • ns: A vertical line segment (North-South).
  • ne: A 90-degree turn connecting North and East.
  • -: Empty cell (not part of the loop).
  • x: Filled cell (not appear if no rule applies, e.g., masyu).

- - - - - - -
- - - - - 1w -
- - - - - - -
"""

# Solve
res = puzzlekit.solve(problem_str, puzzle_type="yajilin")

# Print solution grid
print(res.solution_data.get('solution_grid', []))

# Visualize (optional)
res.show()
